definition: to compete/competition/match/to surpass/better than/superior to/to excel

sentences.english: Have a good rest, you need to save your energy for the tennis match this afternoon.
sentences.chinese: 好好休息，你要爲下午的網球賽節省點精力。

sentences.english: I like to watch tennis matches.
In tennis four points makes a game.
sentences.chinese: 網球賽先得四分算勝一局。

sentences.english: Summer is not summer in Britain without the Wimbledon Tennis Championships.
sentences.chinese: 沒有溫布爾登網球賽的英國夏天，可謂不算是夏天。

sentences.english: How many games are there in the tennis set?
Have a good rest, and you need to save your energy for the tennis match this afternoon.
sentences.chinese: 好好休息，你需要爲今天下午的網球賽保存能量。

sentences.english: She won a narrow victory over her great rival in the tennis competition.
sentences.chinese: 她在那次網球賽中險勝了她的強大對手。

sentences.english: Henman is the golden boy of British tennis this season.
sentences.chinese: 亨曼是本季英國網球賽的寵兒。

sentences.english: He lost the tennis match default.
sentences.chinese: 他因不傣嘗兒輸了網球賽。

sentences.english: They defaulted in the tennis tournament.
sentences.chinese: 在網球賽中他們沒參賽。

sentences.english: The travel show was on hiatus during coverage of Wimbledon.
sentences.chinese: 該旅遊節目因爲轉播溫布頓網球賽而暫停播出。

sentences.english: Who's the winner of the tennis match?
sentences.chinese: 這次網球賽的優勝者是誰？

sentences.english: Who won the tennis game last night?
I have to play in a tennis match on Friday .
sentences.chinese: 星期五我得參加一場網球賽。

sentences.english: I have seen cheerleaders at basketball games but never at tennis tournaments.
sentences.chinese: 偶在籃球賽中看到過啦啦隊，但是網球賽中從來沒有。

sentences.english: Olympic tennis is a knockout competition-one loss and you're out.
sentences.chinese: 奧運會網球賽採用的是淘汰制，輸一輪就徹底被淘汰。

definition: Lee Lai-Shan (1970-), former windsurfing world champion from Hong Kong
organizing committee/abbr. to 組委|组委
Ever Victorious Army (1860-1864), Qing dynasty army equipped and trained jointly with Europeans and used esp. against the Taiping rebels
National Games, Chinese athletics competition, organized every four years since 1959
the right to host (an international meeting)
to snatch gold/to take first place in a competition
